title: d3.geo.centroid: fix handling of mixed geometries.
Fix treemap slice-dice mode.
body:
For even depths, it was falling back to Math.min(rect.dx, rect.dy) instead of always "dicing" (rect.dy).

Your merge broke the conditional slightly, sorry I didn't notice this earlier!

title: Handle spheres in fallback stream.
body:
Includes test.  This was causing an error if the fallback stream was used with spheres.

Previously, clipping would convert any spheres to polygons prior to resampling, but without clipping a sphere can be passed to resampling, and thus to the context.

title: Fix CCW polygon detection issue.
body:
The south pole rotation introduced precision issues for small polygons that ended up at the south pole, so this has been temporarily removed.

The south pole rotation was required to detect polygons winding around the clip edge, but this is rare in practice, so it shouldn't be an issue while I find a permanent fix.

I also reduced the negative ε for negative areas to 1e-6, since the approximation should hold true even for tiny polygons, and this worked fine in the rotation test.

Lastly, I removed a redundant variable from d3.geo.area.

title: Optimise d3.geo.clip area calculation.
body:
Only the area sign is needed to determine the polygon winding order, so a fast approximation is sufficient.

U.S. counties benchmark: 84ms/op → 51ms/op.

title: Force layout using forces instead of dx/dy
body:
Hi Mike,

Happily been using your library for quite some time. I need to show you our web app 'scotty' one time, which uses some really nice technologies and visualizations. Currently I have it hosted internally, but I'm sure I can port-forward it for you.

Now the pull request. I noticed the amount of forces applied to the nodes was smaller on my machine compared with a laptop of a coworker. Also, during 'long' frames, I saw a change in the amount of force. I isolated it to the force layouter, which doesn't take framerate into account.

The commit I added to my repo:
- Use forces instead of dx/dy to calculate next frame proportional to dt (delta-t)
- Allow user to set function for extra calculation of force.
- Drag force added to better simulate fluid environment in addition to friction. Allows simulation of air/water drag.

This creates problems with the examples which most likely need to be updated. Let me know what you think and I'll fix it somewhere next week.

With kind regards,

Edwin de Jong

title: Improve locale parsing in Linux.
body:
Looks like some systems have a slightly different interpretation of the POSIX spec, whereby semicolons are inserted and then the combined values are surrounded by a single pair of double quotes.

[Related](http://www.open-std.org/JTC1/SC22/WG15/docs/rr/9945-2/9945-2-146.html).

title: Resample between first and last ring points, and another distortion fix.
body:
The distortion adjustment fixes this case, where _t - .5 = 0.3947904614820772_.

title: Allow function as argument for append
body: I was running into a problem where I needed to decide which type of element to append to the canvas based on data type and the obvious answer was to use an anonymous function. It looks like this was already being planned given the todos in code and in the [api documentation](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/wiki/Selections#wiki-append).

title: Refactor d3.geo.projection to be more data-driven.
Refactor cutting/clipping into separate files.
body: First pass.  Next step is to make it data-driven!

title: More accurate winding order check.
body: Can be optimised, of course, but this actually handles http://bl.ocks.org/d/3788999/ properly.

title: Add d3.geo.area.
body:
See #941.

Next I'll look at using a version of this for accurate CCW detection.  It's not a straightforward application of this code since we actually want to detect when a ring goes around the antipodal point at the same time, but I think this is possible to do if the area is calculated relative to the antipode rather than the South Pole.

Then… area-weighted polygon centroids. :)

title: Add d3.geo.centroid.
body:
Polygons are temporarily treated as lines while I work on adding area weighting.

See #941.

title: Take into account clipping when computing areas and centroids.
body:
Working on:
- ~~Polygon centroids.~~
- ~~Other centroids: presumably we should ignore clipped segments and points.~~
- ~~Compute areas on-the-fly.~~

title: Fix path.centroid for polygons with holes.
body:
The centroid was not being subtracted for interior polygon rings
(holes), hence it was appearing too far to the right.  The winding order
is ignored.

title: Xhr function callback
body:
If d3.xhr is redefined as a function (another way to set the callback) it can be used directly with queue.js without having to wrap inside a bespoke function.  

```
queue()
     .defer(d3.csv("fileA.csv").get())
     .defer(d3.csv("fileB.csv").get())
     .await(......
```

For some reason this pull request includes a previous commit (CORS support) by Mike and blends them together.  Don't understand why, feel free to just close.  In any case the idea here is to remove `xhr = {}` and replace with `function xhr(callback) { on.load(callback...)}`

title: Disabling zoom on right click
body: https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups=#!topic/d3-js/zRhHR5vhZYc

title: d3.geo.projection benchmarks and performance improvement.
body:
Dense graticule: 140→110ms/op.
Circle polygons: 69→61ms/op.
Spiral polygons: 3.3→2.6ms/op.

title: Improve Polygon clipping.
body:
1. We no longer perform an equality check on GeoJSON polygon endpoints, since we know that the first and last points should be equal.
2. However, there are special cases where a polygon just touches the clip edge, generating two coincident intersection points.  Here we avoid generating a coincident point, and continue as normal.
3. Another special case is where we have coincident intersection points e.g. due to a self-intersecting polygon.  Here we continue calculating the winding number as if this is a closed polygon (so we know whether to insert a polygon around the whole clip edge).

title: Improve Polygon clipping.
body:
Specifically, endpoints are no longer checked for equality, since precision errors can cause this check to fail.  In fact, we don't even care if the endpoints aren't equal; we just check for intersections instead.

This also includes a test for d3.geo.circle coordinates, which led to the above fix since the endpoints aren't exactly equal.

title: Fix d3.geo.circle Polygon.
body: It was missing a closing point.
